page.title: 03Landscape - PhysicaL
page.content: Geologically, the area is composed of Silurian slates and grits, giving rise to thin, acid soils on the whole. However, the effects of glaciation are frequently to be seen, mainly in the form of moraine deposits smoothing the craggy outlines of much of the countryside. Close to the lake, at Millerground, Queen Adelaide's Hill is a particularly large glacial deposit of drumlin shape. The lake itself lies in an over-deepened glacial trough, shelving steeply along most of its shoreline towards a deepest point of about 62m. The glacial deposits have made a lot of difference to soil depth and fertility, where they occur. Drainage is mainly towards the east, via the small river Gowen, which rises on the slopes of Sour Howes and flows in to the river Kent at Staveley.
